results.title: Chi: the breath of life
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Healers quacks or mystics”.
In this episode, Nevill Drury visits the Oki East-West Centre to investigate disciplines which draw on eastern thought and philosophy for new directions in health care. “Chi” is the Chinese word for breath of life, an inner energy. The Chinese believe it is the source of remarkable power, so the ability to control this energy is vital for a healthy and happy life. In a healthy person, the “Chi” flows smoothly, integrating body, mind and spirit, but in an unwell person there are blockages, or imbalances. The techniques demonstrated include Oki Yoga, Tai Chi, Shiatsu (with Bruce Gyngell as the patient), macrobiotics and acupuncture.

results.title: The Hidden universe: the brain. Parts 1 and 2
results.creator_credit: Tom Bywaters, American Broadcasting Company and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Provides an overview of the functions of the brain, including motor control, memory and sensory perceptions. Shows doctors performing a craniotomy, probing different parts of the patient’s brain, and indicating the sensations that this causes. Discusses also the separate functions of the right and left cranial hemispheres. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Heatwave lasted four days
results.creator_credit: Douglas Jackson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A few meters of film, the tempting lure of several thousand dollars, and a television-news cameraman with a weakness for wine, women and cars becomes an accomplice in crime. In this fast-moving murder feature, which links intrigue with intrigue, we witness the progressive ruination of a man who can find no way out.

results.title: Healers quacks or mystics
results.creator_credit: Bernice Daly, Brian Nicholls, Richard Corfield and ABC
results.brief_description: Alternative medicine offers us many options. Some approaches focus more on healthy body, others on healthy mind. But in all there is a common underlying theme, and that is that the individual can do a lot to keep themselves well. We don’t have to prop ourselves up with pills, or overload our bodies with junk food and stress. In this series, Nevill Drury takes us through a wide range of alternative therapies and treatments now available in Australia.

results.title: Risk factors
results.creator_credit: Roger Hudson, Jim Dale, Mediacast, National Heart Foundation of Australia and Suatu Film Management
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Help yourself to health”.
Focuses on the main risk factors in coronary heart disease: prolonged high blood pressure, smoking, excessive fat in diet leading to elevated blood cholesterol levels.

results.title: The Bodyworkers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Healers quacks or mystics”.
Bodyworkers use a range of techniques to release tension and anxiety in the body in order to release energy for life and healing. Bodyworkers believe the body holds secrets for our health and that our society’s over-emphasis on the mind, destroys the important mind/body balance. Techniques demonstrated include massage, the Alexander technique for improving posture, Rolfing (developed by US biologist, Dr. Ida Rolf) and Wilhelm Reich’s theories of sexual energy and release.

results.title: The Golden dragons
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Dean Lawry and Kim Montgomery
results.brief_description: Bendigo - Bendigo’s annual Easter parade has featured the Dragon and Lion dancers from the Bendigo Chinese Association for over 100 years. This mini documentary explores how this historical tradition has helped shape the identities of the dancers and features interviews combined with footage of their colourful and exciting dance held at dusk at the Dragons’ spiritual home - Bendigo’s Golden Dragon Museum of Australia

results.title: The Guan Yin Temple
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Dean Lawry and Kim Montgomery
results.brief_description: In this interview, Ralph Beh - a curator at the Golden Dragon Museum in Bendigo dicusses the history and significance of the remarkable murals that adorn the inner walls of the Guan Yin temple on the museum’s grounds.

results.title: Friends of the Bendigo Botanical Gardens
results.brief_description: Bendigo is better known for its old historic buildings than its heritage listed Botanic Gardens. Jan Orr, Rodney Orr and Glenys Anthony, members of the Friends of the Bendigo Botanic Gardens, talk about the history and some of the features of the Conservatory Gardens, including the rose garden and the fernery. The aim of the “Friends” group is to promote, protect and restore Bendigo’s heritage listed gardens.
